Key Laboratory of Jiangxi Province for Environment and Energy Catalysis, Institute of Applied Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanchang University Nanchang 330031 China Zeolites are important catalysts for the synthesis of 2,6-dimethylnaphthalene (2,6-DMN) by the raw materials of 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN) and C10 aromatics. However, the selectivity of 2,6-DMN is still difficult to control and the catalysts often suffer from poor hydrothermal stability. In this work, a series of Mo-modified HZSM-12 catalysts were prepared and investigated for the transalkylation reaction between 2-MN and C10 aromatics under a hydrogen atmosphere. The introduction of Mo binds to the B-acid sites on the molecular sieves, modulating the B-acid strength and content of the catalysts while also altering their pore structure. As a result, the 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance, the conversion of 2-MN could still reach up to 61.3 % and the ratio of 2,6-/2,7-DMN was able to reach 1.69 after 6 h of the reaction. Therefore, our work is expected to provide a useful strategy for constructing efficient zeolite catalysts for the synthesis of high-value esters’ precursors. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mo/HZSM-12 2 6-dimethylnaphthalene Zeolite Alkyl transfer Shape-selective catalysis Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN) is an important organic chemical raw material used as a precursor for 2,6-dimethylnaphthalene (2,6-DMN), which can be further applied to the preparation of polyethylene naphthalene dicarboxylate (PEN) [1,2]. PEN is a new generation of high-performance polyester material with superior mechanical properties, heat resistance, gas barrier, and chemical stability [3]. However, the immaturity of 2,6-DMN production technology has limited the large-scale production of PEN. Recently, the transalkylation (alkylation) reaction of 2-MN with C10 aromatics (C10A) is considered a useful method for the production of 2,6-DMN. In the past decades, C10A were mainly derived from heavy aromatics reforming in the petroleum refining process, cracked gasoline heavy aromatics, and by-products of high-temperature coal coking [4]. Nevertheless, due to the complex compositions of C10A, which include hundreds of substances such as polymethylbenzene, naphthalene, and alkyl naphthalene, the separation and deep processing of the heavy aromatic hydrocarbons are difficult. This results in the heavy aromatic hydrocarbons having not been fully utilized until now. With the development of oil refining technology and petrochemical industry, the output of C10A has been increasing year by year. Therefore, how to develop the use of C10A has become a research hotspot [5]. It is highly suggested to operate the transalkylation reaction between C10A and 2-MN to prepare high-value 2,6-DMN [6,7]. In transalkylation procedures, the low-cost C10A can be employed as transmethylation reagent in addition to solvents for 2-MN. In addition, with the lightweighting of C10A, high value-added organic chemical raw materials, such as BTX [8] and C6∼C8 light aromatics can be produced [9]. Due to the ease of process and broad range of raw material sources, the one-step synthesis of 2,6-DMN by 2-MN with C10A or methanol has generated a lot of interests [10–17]. However, there are a total of 10 isomers of dimethylnaphthalene. Because of the structural features, the boiling points of these isomers are very close to each other, especially 2,6-DMN and 2,7-DMN only differ by 0.3 ◦C, which makes it difficult to isolate and purify 2,6-DMN. Therefore, the key to improving the yield of 2,6-DMN lies in the development of a highly selective catalytic route [18–25]. Zeolites are a class of porous crystalline silica-aluminate materials with abundant microporous structure. The pore size of these micropores is comparable to the size of many molecules, which has a sieving effect, and thus it is called molecular sieve [26]. As molecular sieves have special pore structures and acidic sites, they can show different selectivity in catalytic reactions according to their pore structures and acidic sites [27], which makes them exhibit good shape-selective effects in the alkylation of methylnaphthalene with methanol [26,28]. Previously, various micro-mesoporous zeolite catalysts such as HZSM-5 [29–31], HZSM-12 [23,32], USY [33], HMordenite zeolite [6], HMCM-22 [27], HBeta [17], and SAPO-11 [34] have been reported to be used for the synthesis of 2,6-DMN with good results. For example, Li et al. synthesized hierarchical ZSM-5 with a controlled chain structure by hydrothermal synthesis [35]. As the sucrose content of the precursor increased, the chain hierarchical structure became more pronounced, which also led to more mesopores in ZSM-5. It was suggested that the conversion of 2-MN remained above 20 % after 10 h of reactions when the sucrose/SiO2 ratio is 0.5 in the catalyst. Ye et al. adopted an ion-exchange method to modify the catalysts and explored the performance in the 2-MN alkylation reaction. The introduction of Mg2+ changed the original acidity and some acid sites of the catalysts, thus enhancing the selectivity and stability [36]. Li et al. designed an innovative methylation technique for the inexpensive synthesis of 2,6-dimethylnaphthalene that used low-cost C10A as the solvent and transmethylation reagent, which involved the transalkylation reaction of 2-MN with C10A and 2-MN under H2 atmosphere using SiO2(II)-3.0 %Ni-H-mordenite as the catalyst [6]. The transalkylation reaction resulted in more than 67.1 % conversion of 2-MN and more than 10.7 % yield of 2,6-dimethylnaphthalene. Overall, zeolites have made excellent progress in 2-MN alkylation reactions. However, there are few reports on HZSM-12 molecular sieves catalyzing transalkylation of C10A with 2-MN to synthesize 2,6-DMN. In addition, the poor stability of most catalysts in alkylation reactions and the use of large amounts of solvents in the feedstock have led to industrial limitations. ZSM-12 is a high silica molecular sieve with MTW configuration, and its pore structure is a one-dimensional twelve-membered ring of linear non-crossing pores with an orifice size of about 0.57 × 0.61 nm. Some of the scholars obtained that the diffusion energy barriers of 2,6-DMN in ZSM-12 molecular sieves were lower and those of 2,7-DMN were higher according to molecular dynamics simulations, and the difference in the energy barriers of diffusion between the two in their structural pores was nearly 10 times, which was favorable for screening alkylation products and improving the selectivity of 2,6-DMN [2,37]. Therefore, ZSM-12 is an ideal zeolite catalyst for the preparation of 2,6-DMN. Moreover, it has been reported that the molecular sieves modified by metal Mo would have efficient synergistic catalytic effects between metal and Lewis (L) & Brönsted (B) acid sites [16]. In this work, HZSM-12 catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal method, and then a series of Mo-modified HZSM-12 catalysts with different concentrations were synthesized by impregnation method. Finally, these zeolites were used as catalysts for the efficient transalkylation reaction of C10A with 2-MN under H2 atmosphere, where the C10A was used as a solvent and transalkylation reagent. The results showed that the catalyst exhibited good catalytic performance and stability, which was further revealed by a series of characterizations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The C10A was provided from Shandong Chambroad Petrochemicals Co. Ltd., China. Silica sol (40 % SiO2) was provided from Haoyao New Materials Co. Ltd., China. Tetraethylammonium hydroxide (25 % TEAOH) was provided from Yancheng Fine Chem Co. Ltd., China. Sodium aluminate (NaAlO2 AR), Ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (AR), and 2-methylnaphthalene (AR) were purchased from Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd., China. All reagents were commercially received without further purification. Deionized water was homemade. 2.2 Catalyst preparation ZSM-12 molecular sieves were synthesized by the traditional hydrothermal method, and its molar chemical composition was as follows: 0.24 TEAOH: 5.3 H2O: 0.0167 NaO2: 0.0083 Al2O3: 1 SiO2. The specific process was as follows: deionized water was added to the polytetrafluoroethylene liner, and then a certain amount of sodium aluminate and tetraethylammonium hydroxide template agent was added. After stirring, the liner was put into the reactor and crystallized in the oven at 160 ◦C for six days. Finally, the gel was filtered with deionized water, and then it was put in an oven at 80 ◦C for one night, and then put into an oven at 550 ◦C for 6 h. Na-ZSM-12 was added to ammonium nitrate solution at 80 ◦C for 6 h, then filtered and dried. This step was repeated three times and finally calcined at 550 ◦C for 4 h to obtain HZSM-12. A series of Mo-modified HZSM-12 molecular sieves were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. First, the water absorption rate of HZSM-12 was calculated from the mass of the HZSM-12 sample before and after water absorption. Then, based on the mass and water absorption rate of HZSM-12, the mass of the active component precursor required for impregnation was calculated, and it was prepared into an equal volume of impregnation solution. Finally, HZSM-12 was placed in a container, an equal volume of impregnation solution was added and stirred thoroughly, and after impregnation for a period of time, it was calcined at 550 ◦C for 2 h to obtain the Mo-modified HZSM-12 samples. The specific preparation of Mo-modified HZSM-12 molecular sieves using (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O was carried out as follows: 0.0459, 0.0919, 0.1379, and 0.1839 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4 H2O were added to deionized water and 2.5 g of HZSM-12 molecular sieves were added to the solution. The modified molecular sieves were dried in the oven at 80 ◦C for 12 h and calcined at 550 ◦C for 4 h to obtain catalysts loaded with different amounts of Mo, named x%Mo/HZSM-12 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4). 2.3 Characterizations The morphology and size of all sample powders were analyzed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-4800). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was operated on a JEOL JEM 2100 F equipment. The inductively coupled plasma (ICP) results of actual Mo loading over the catalysts were measured by an Agilent 5100 ICP-OES. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were tested with an XD-3 X-ray diffractometer with the scanning rate of 2◦/min (5–50◦). The N2 physisorption properties of all the samples are measured by the Micromeritics ASAP2020 set-up. The pyridine-IR analysis (Py-IR) was obtained from Thermo fisher Nicolet iS50 instruments. The test method of Py-IR was as follows: The prepared samples were pressed and fixed in the infrared cell, which was first vacuum pretreated (350 ◦C). Then it was cooled to room temperature, and scanned spectra were used as background. After adsorption of pyridine at room temperature, the program was warmed up to the measurement temperature (200, 300, and 400 ◦C) for desorption and then cooled down to room temperature to record the infrared spectra in the region of 1700–1400 cm⁻¹ wave number. The data at 1540 and 1450 cm−1 were selected for calculation as B and L acids in Py-IR. More detailed formulas have been depicted in the Supporting Information. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed on an Auto Chem from Micromeritics, Inc. 2920. The test method of NH3-TPD was as follows: 50 mg catalyst was heated in a hydrogen flow at a rate of 10 ◦C/min to 500 ◦C and then the sample was in-situ reduced for 60 min. Then it was purged by a He flow at 500 ◦C for 90 min, then adsorbed with 0.5 % NH3-N2 mixture at 50 ◦C for 60 min, and then purged the excess NH3 by He gas flow. Finally, the system was heated to 500 ◦C (10 ◦C/min) and the desorbed NH3 was detected by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Thermogravimetric analysis of the catalysts was performed on a Discovery TGA55 instrument. The XPS test was performed with an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer ESCALAB25OXI instrument. Fourier infrared (FTIR) spectra were collected by Agilent Cary 630. In the catalyst background, KBr was used as the reference, and the spectral resolution was 4 cm−1. 2.4 Catalytic reaction Transalkylation of 2-MN and C10A was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor using Mo/HZSM-12 molecular sieves as catalysts. The collected products were injected into the GC by taking 0.3 μL of a sample using a 0.5 μL injector and rinsing with the sample 20–30 times before each injection. During the sample injection process, ensure that the amount of sample is accurate and the injection is uniform. Before the GC is used, it was purged with nitrogen for ten minutes. The temperatures of the injection port, column oven, and detector were set as 280, 159, and 300 ◦C, respectively. Finally, the hydrogen and air valves were opened to control the temperature, and after the temperature reached the set temperature, the sample can be analyzed. More details are depicted in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of the Mo/HZSM-12 catalysts The XRD analysis was carried out to investigate the physical phase composition and crystal structure of the various catalysts, and the results are presented in Fig. 1. The position and intensity of each distinctive diffraction peak of HZSM-12 zeolites are consistent with the previous results (PDF No. 43–0439). The diffraction peaks of the Mo-modified zeolite are basically the same as those of their precursors, and there are no other stray peaks or new diffraction peaks. This indicates that the structure of the catalysts was not disrupted and no new phases were generated during the Mo loading process, which indicates the successful synthesis of Mo/HZSM-12 molecular sieves. Diffraction peaks of the MoO3 were also not observed, which was mostly caused by the low loading of Mo and the uniform distribution of the active metal Mo on the catalyst, and these results were further confirmed in the following TEM results. N2 physisorption was used to reveal the catalysts’ physical properties and the impact of Mo modification on the pore structure of HZSM-12 zeolites. Fig. 2 shows the N2 physisorption curves of HZSM-12 molecular sieves before and after modification [18]. All the catalysts exhibited type IV isotherms and H4-type hysteresis loops, demonstrating the existence of both microporous and mesoporous structures in all catalysts. From Fig. 2b, it can be seen that Mo modification has no significant effect on the pore distribution of the catalysts. Most of the pore sizes of both HZSM-12 and Mo-modified HZSM-12 are concentrated between 3 and 4 nm, and all the molecular sieves exhibit mesoporous structures. Moreover, as shown in Table 1, the specific surface area (SBET) and pore volume of Mo/HZSM-12 molecular sieves were slightly decreased compared with that of the parent HZSM-12. Notably, when the concentration of Mo increases, the decrease in the SBET of the catalyst becomes more pronounced. This is possible because Mo species are not only covered on the surface of HZSM-12 molecular sieves but also deposited in the molecular sieve pore channels, resulting in a smaller molecular sieve pore volume. On the other hand, the small-sized Mo species were loaded into the pore channels or orifices, thus occupying the pore space or even blocking some of the pore channels, while the Mo nanoclusters with larger outer surfaces also blocked some of the pore channels. The content of Mo in the Mo/HZSM-12 catalysts was tested by ICP and the Mo loading was listed in Table 1. The actual Mo loading of modified HZSM-12 molecular sieve catalysts was 0.74, 1.77, 3.14, and 3.94 %, respectively, which are consistent well with the theoretical Mo contents. EDS analysis of the 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 catalysts is shown in Fig. S4, and specific elemental content information is listed in Table S1. From Table S1, the EDS analysis gives the Mo mass fraction of 2.55 % for the 3 % Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst, which is similar to the value of 3.11 % from the ICP test. The TEM images in Fig. 3 suggest that the 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 molecular sieves are cubic crystals with a relatively uniform particle size of approximately 900 nm. The TEM images of 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 molecular sieves at different magnifications are shown in Fig. 3a-b. Mapping images of 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 in Fig. 3c demonstrate that the active metal Mo was loaded evenly on the catalyst. A series of results showed that the active metal Mo was successfully and uniformly loaded on the HZSM-12 catalysts, which can be confirmed by the results in Table 1. Moreover, the SEM images of HZSM-12 and other concentrations of Mo-modified samples are provided in Fig. S1. It can be seen that the morphology of HZSM-12 catalysts did not change with the increase of Mo loading concentration, and all of them showed uniform cubic crystalline particles in the range of 900–1000 nm. This indicates that the Mo modification did not destroy the structure of HZSM-12, which was also confirmed by the results of XRD. Fig. 4 displays the NH3-TPD results of HZSM-12 and Mo/HZSM-12 samples. It indicates that the catalysts have two signal peaks around 150 ◦C and 280 ◦C, respectively. To verify whether the TCD signal around 150 ◦C is due to the physically adsorbed NH3 or to weak acidic sites, SiO2 (which is essentially acid-free) was selected as a blank experiment. As can be seen in Fig. S9, the sample did not show any peaks before 150 ◦C, which indicates that there is no physisorbed NH3 at this condition. Generally speaking, the peak around 150 ◦C is the desorption peak of weak acid sites, and the peak at 280 ◦C is the desorption peak of medium-strong acid sites. The acid intensity of the sample of Mo-modified HZSM-12 decreased, in which the peaks of weak and medium-strong acids were shifted to the low-temperature region. As shown in Table S2, the relative contents of different acids over Mo/HZSM-12 were obtained by decomposing the peaks of NH3-TPD. With the increase of Mo loading, the content of strong acid of the catalyst is decreasing while the content of weak acid is increasing. This may be because the unsaturated structure formed by Mo with the B acid sites on the molecular sieve [38], which is also consistent with the result of Py-IR, and the B acid content of the Mo-modified catalysts decreased in Table 2. The introduction of Mo modulated the acidity of HZSM-12 by exchanging with the structure of coordinate-unsaturated Mo species produced by the exchange of surface B-acid sites on the HZSM-12 [38–40], which led to a decrease in the B-acid content. Moreover, it can be seen from the 27Al MAS NMR of HZSM-12 and 3 % Mo/HZSM-12 that while Mo interacts with the molecular sieve, part of the skeletal aluminum was shed to become non-skeletal aluminum to form L acid sites. Another part of the reason may be that Mo loaded on the surface of the catalysts and covered some acidic sites. The acidic strength of Mo-modified HZSM-12 decreased compared with unloaded HZSM-12. This resulted in the inhibition of the deep alkylation of the naphthalene and was also responsible for the increased selectivity of 2,6-DMN after Mo loading. However, the content of both weak and strong acids increased over 4 %Mo/HZSM-12 compared to HZSM-12. This may be due to the higher Mo content leading to the generation of Al2(MoO4)3 structure from MoO3 and AlOx species [40]. To further distinguish the types of acidity on the catalyst surface, the catalyst was analyzed by Py-IR. The amount of adsorbed pyridine adsorption varies with temperature, and the amount of acid measured at lower temperatures contains acids of various strengths, whereas strong acids are obtained at higher temperatures. Therefore, the distribution of acid strengths was measured by the TPD method ( Fig. 5). The result obtained from the 200 ◦C measurement corresponded to the total acid amount of the catalyst, while the desorption at 300 and 400 ◦C indicated the amount of strong acids in the catalyst. Compared to HZSM-12, the content of strong acids decreased for 3 %Mo/HZSM-12, which is consistent with the results of NH3-TPD. From Fig. 5, we could also analyze the type and relative content of acids on the catalysts surface [41]. The absorption peak of L acid sites was around 1598 and 1446 cm−1, and the absorption peak of B acid sites was around 1631 and 1542 cm−1. 1492 cm−1 is assigned to both L acid and B acid [42]. Table 2 further shows detailed acidity information for the raw catalyst and 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 sample. The results indicate that both the original zeolite and the modified catalyst exhibit abundant B acid and L acid sites. By further comparing the contents of B acid and L acid sites of the two samples, we can find that HZSM-12 modified by 3 %Mo could increase the content of L acid while the content of B acid showed a trend of decrease compared with the original sample [23]. The results indicate that the addition of Mo could promote the increase of L acid content and the decrease of B acid content on the catalyst surface. The coordination environment of molybdenum species is a key issue in the study of its catalytic function. Based on previous literature, as well as FT-IR (Fig. S8), Py-IR, and XPS (Fig. S7) results, we simulated the coordination environment of Mo in HZSM-12. According to the XPS spectra, Mo species mainly exist as Mo6+ in HZSM-12. The Mo species enters the zeolite in the form of MoO3 and binds with the bridging hydroxyl groups on the B acid sites, forming (MoO2(OH))+. Then, the two (MoO2(OH))+ groups underwent a dehydration condensation to form the (Mo2O5)2+ dimer. The B-acid content decreased due to the substitution of the proton H on the B-acid sites, whereas the increase in the L-acid sites is due to the backbone loading of the metal Mo, which creates sites that can accept electrons. A possible process of Mo binding to the B acid on HZSM-12 is shown in Fig. 6. It demonstrates the process of Mo binding to HZSM-12 (Fig. 6a) and shows the distribution of [Mo2O5]2+ units in the channels of Mo/HZSM-12 (Fig. 6b-c). 3.2 Catalytic results Fig. 7a depicts the variation of 2-MN conversion with reaction time over Mo-modified HZSM-12 catalysts. The conversion of 2-MN with C10A was catalyzed by Mo/HZSM-12 zeolites at 400 ◦C. The initial conversion of 2-MN in pure HZSM-12 zeolite was 52.4 %. The conversion of 2-MN was still maintained at 48.1 % after 6 h of reaction. However, the initial conversion of 2-MN in the 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst was improved from 52.4 % to 64.2 %, which indicates that the Mo modification effectively improved the activity of the original HZSM-12 catalyst and maintained the stability of the original catalyst. The conversion of 2-MN was maintained at 61.3 % after 6 h of reaction over 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst, and the specific distribution of DMNs in the transalkylation products at 1.0 h is presented in Table 3. In addition, more catalytic properties of other molecular sieves in transalkylation reactions are presented in Fig. S2. Fig. 7b demonstrates the selectivity of 2,6-DMN over all the Mo/HZSM-12 samples. The initial 2,6-DMN selectivity of the HZSM-12 catalyst was 13.4 % after 1 h of the reaction, while the initial 2,6-DMN selectivities of the 1 %Mo/HZSM-12 and 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 samples were 21.1 % and 18.4 % after 6 h of the reaction, respectively. The selectivity of the Mo-modified HZSM-12 catalyst was superior to that of the pure HZSM-12 zeolite, and the ratio of 2,6-/2,7-DMN over 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst and pure HZSM-12 catalyst is shown in Fig. S3. After 6 hours of reaction, the ratio of 2,6-/2,7-DMN was only 1.06 over HZSM-12 catalyst, whereas the ratio of 2,6-/2,7-DMN maintained 1.69 over 3 %Mo/HZSM-12. Fig. 7c illustrates the variation of the yield of 2,6-DMN over time for the Mo/HZSM-12 catalysts. The yield of 2,6-DMN over 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst was higher than other samples. Comparing the pure zeolite with the Mo-modified zeolites, it can be seen from Fig. 7c that the 2,6-DMN yield of the HZSM-12 zeolite was lower and less stable, and it decreased to 1.7 % after 6 h of the reaction. In contrast, 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 zeolite was improved and more stable, and the yield of 2,6-DMN still reached 4.8 % after 6 h of reaction. TG analysis for HZSM-12 and 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 samples were also performed. As shown in Fig. 7d, the weight loss of catalysts below 250 ◦C was caused by the removal of adsorbed water on the surface. However, the weight loss of catalysts at 300–800 ◦C was ascribed to the decomposition of coke within the molecular sieve pores [43,44]. The 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 have the same lower weight loss not only below 250 ◦C but also above 250 ◦C. This indicated that the Mo-modified samples have better anti-carbon deposition properties. Lower carbon deposition rate implied better stability of the catalyst, mainly because excessive carbon deposition can clog the molecular sieve pores and lead to catalyst deactivation. 3.3 Catalytic discussion During the transalkylation reaction, seven positions on the naphthalene ring of 2-MN can be substituted, and there are ten isomers of DMN generated in the reaction, mainly α,α-DMN, α,β-DMN, and β,β-DMN. The potential mechanism of the transalkylation reaction over Mo/HZSM-12 is represented in Fig. 8. Transalkylation is a B acid-catalyzed carbocation reaction [45], and the acidic center of the molecular sieve and the C10A interact. Thus, the methyl group at a certain position on the C10A is removed to generate the carbocation, and then the carbocation attacks the naphthalene ring of the 2-MN, in which the generation of the carbocation is the decisive step of the transalkylation reaction [21,46]. In summary, the strength of the acidity of the catalyst directly influences the catalytic performance, thus suitable acidity is important for transalkylation reactions. In this work, Mo was used to modify HZSM-12 molecular sieves. Based on the characterization of NH3-TPD and Py-IR, the acid strength of the catalyst decreased after Mo modification, which not only reduced the possibility of isomerization of the reaction products but also inhibited the further alkylation of DMNs to generate poly(methylnaphthalene) and the selectivity of 2,6-DMN was thus improved. Transalkylation is also a shape-selective catalytic reaction [21], and β,β-DMN has the smallest molecular dynamics diameter among the ten DMNs. Therefore, appropriate pore structure and diameter are also important for improving the selectivity of 2,6-DMN. Similarly, from the results of SBET, the SBET and pore volume of the HZSM-12 molecular sieves decreased after Mo modification, which could be attributed to the fact that the Mo species adhered to the surface and the pore of the zeolites. The pore size of the molecular sieves became smaller, which resulted in a specific shape-selective catalytic effect and improved the selectivity of 2,6-DMN. The hydrogen atmosphere is favorable for the transalkylation reaction because hydrogen molecules decomposed into hydrogen atoms after being adsorbed onto the metallic Mo nanoclusters’ active surface [16]. The latter produced a hydrogen overflow effect and migrated to the acidic surface of the HZSM-12 molecular sieves, and then interacted with the acid sites to be converted into active hydrogen [47]. This behavior accelerates the proton transfer efficiency at the catalyst surface, which in turn increases the activity of the transalkylation reaction catalyzed mainly by B acid sites. Moreover, the presence of hydrogen also led to the efficient decomposition of the multi-carbon olefins produced in the reaction, avoiding the generation of carbon deposits. Therefore, Mo modification weakened the acidity of the molecular sieves and avoided the deep alkylation of DMNs. Mo deposition had a certain degree of passivation effect on the surface of the zeolites, which resulted in a decrease in SBET and a change in the pore structure, and the pore confinement of the molecular sieves by the metal modification was favorable to the selective diffusion of the products. Meanwhile, there was a synergistic effect between the catalysts and the hydrogen after the Mo modification, thus the activity of the catalyst as well as the coking resistivity was improved. 4 Conclusions In summary, this work introduces HZSM-12 and four Mo/HZSM-12 catalysts for the transalkylation reaction of 2-MN with C10A as the solvent and the transmethylation reagent under H2 atmosphere. The structure-property relationship was scientifically explored by a series of characterization methods, and it could be concluded that the Mo modification would not damage the primitive structure of HZSM-12 catalysts. Meanwhile, it was able to regulate the percentage of B acid and L acid in the catalyst, and reduced the acidic strength of the catalyst, thereby inhibiting the formation of by-products. In addition, the synergistic catalytic effect of the acidic sites of the catalyst and metal Mo accelerated the migration rate of protons on the catalyst surface and thus improved the activity of the transalkylation reaction. Therefore, the Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst has good selectivity and stability due to the shape-selective catalytic effect of the molecular sieves and the rational catalytic hydrogenation effectively preventing the generation of carbon deposits. The work offers a rational way to synthesize 2,6-DMN by using C10A and zeolites. coredata.dc:description: Zeolites are important catalysts for the synthesis of 2,6-dimethylnaphthalene (2,6-DMN) by the raw materials of 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN) and C10 aromatics. However, the selectivity of 2,6-DMN is still difficult to control and the catalysts often suffer from poor hydrothermal stability. In this work, a series of Mo-modified HZSM-12 catalysts were prepared and investigated for the transalkylation reaction between 2-MN and C10 aromatics under a hydrogen atmosphere. The introduction of Mo binds to the B-acid sites on the molecular sieves, modulating the B-acid strength and content of the catalysts while also altering their pore structure. As a result, the 3 %Mo/HZSM-12 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance, the conversion of 2-MN could still reach up to 61.3 % and the ratio of 2,6-/2,7-DMN was able to reach 1.69 after 6 h of the reaction. Therefore, our work is expected to provide a useful strategy for constructing efficient zeolite catalysts for the synthesis of high-value esters’ precursors.

coredata.dc:title: Transalkylation between C10 aromatics and 2-methylnaphthalene to synthesize 2,6-dimethylnaphthalene by Mo-modified HZSM-12 catalysts
